title-group.article-title: Taguchi-Method-Based CFD Study and Optimisation of Personalised Ventilation Systems

article-meta.aff: Department of Civil, Environmental and Architectural Engineering, University of Colorado at Boulder, Boulder, Colorado 80309-0428, USA

author-notes.corresp: Zhiqiang (John) Zhai, Department of Civil, Environmental and Architectural Engineering, University of Colorado at Boulder, Boulder, Colorado 80309-0428, USA. Tel. 303 492 4699, Fax 303 492 7317, E-Mail John.Zhai@colorado.edu

permissions.copyright-holder: International Society of the Built Environment

abstract.p: This paper presents a Taguchi-method-based approach that can quickly and accurately predict the operating performance of personalised ventilation (PV) systems using limited computational fluid dynamics simulation results. This method was used to optimise the operation characteristics (supply air temperature, velocity and flow rate) of a new PV air terminal device (ATD) design with the goal of achieving an overall best performance of thermal comfort, indoor air quality (IAQ) and energy efficiency. With the new ATD system, supply air temperature was found to have a significant influence on thermal comfort, IAQ and energy; volume flow rate was found to have a significant effect on IAQ and minor effects on thermal comfort and energy; and supply air velocity was found to have insignificant effects on all performance characteristics. Two new methods were developed to rapidly identify optimal system parameters for the best overall performance. Multiple solutions were obtained for the optimised system where improvements in thermal comfort, IAQ and energy performance were achieved in comparison to a system with mixing ventilation only.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Personalised ventilation (PV) provides fresh air directly into the breathing zone (BZ) and individual control of the thermal environment. PV can provide cool dry air, which has been found to be more acceptable to occupants [1] with reduced mixing in the BZ lowering the rate of people dissatisfied [2]. Previous research conducted on PV has shown improvements in thermal comfort and indoor air quality (IAQ) for building occupants along with reduced energy consumption. Thermal comfort can have a critical effect on the occupant's productivity, mood and health. PV has been shown in previous studies to improve occupant thermal comfort [3,4] especially in hot and humid climates [5–7]. IAQ is a large concern in buildings because of airborne gas and particle contaminants, viruses and other illnesses can be spread or caused by poor indoor environment designs. Studies have shown that PV reduces pollutant concentration in the BZ [8,9] and contributes to healthier work environment [10,11]. With increasing concerns about the energy and climate change, new measures to reduce energy are being explored. Research conducted on cooling applications showed that PV has an energy savings potential of 30%–45% over a conventional mixing system [12,13].

Both experimental and simulation approaches were found in the literature for various PV studies. Computational fluid dynamics (CFD) has been used widely to validate previous work and test new PV supply conditions, air terminal devices (ATDs) and other operating characteristics [14–17]. CFD is relatively inexpensive, quick, and more versatile when compared to physical experiments, and is capable of producing results that contribute to the evaluation of PV in terms of thermal comfort, IAQ and energy savings potential. Previous work using CFD for PV has been instrumental in the development and optimisation of various ATDs that have led to commercially available products, such as Climadesk (Advanced Ergonomic Technologies).

This paper presents a straightforward and repeatable CFD-based method that can accurately predict the optimal operating conditions of PV systems. In contrast to previous studies, the optimal performance of the PV system, presented in this paper, includes the influences of various operation characteristics (supply air velocity, flow rate and temperature) on three critical performance factors: thermal comfort, IAQ and energy savings. This method is able to predict more achievable and comprehensive operating performance of PV systems. The paper uses the development of a new ATD as a case study to illustrate how the method can be employed to optimise a new PV design.

sec.title: CFD Method
sec.p: CFD has been widely used for indoor environment study by providing valuable insight on various important environment characteristics, such as the distributions of air velocity, temperature, relative humidity and contaminant concentration. These factors can be used to calculate various performance indices such as Predicted Mean Vote (PMV) for thermal comfort, Age of Air for IAQ and kWatt for cooling/heating energy required by the space. CFD is extremely beneficial for design research, allowing for more variables to be measured with greater flexibility of input variations than experimentation.

This research used a commercial CFD software [18], to perform the CFD analysis. The Renormalised Group (RNG) k-ε model [19], a variation of the Two-Equation Eddy-Viscosity Standard k-ε model, was used to solve the Reynolds Average Navier-Stokes (RANS) equations. The RNG k-ε model provides better results than the standard k-ε model and is widely used for simulations of airflow in enclosed environments [20]. Also, when compared to other turbulence models, the RNG k-ε showed the best overall performances in terms of accuracy, computing efficiency and robustness [21].

Several simplifications and assumptions were made to create a proper CFD model. As the research focuses on the global and regional airflow patterns in a ventilated room as well as ventilation system design, the less detailed block-shaped seated occupant without respiration can be used with reasonable accuracy [22]. The Boussinesq approximation was used to account for the buoyancy effects on the airflow. The CFD simulation solved air pressure, velocity, temperature, turbulence and age of air but did not solve the radiation heat transfer and humidity ratio change. Radiation heat was introduced into the space through the envelope surface temperatures. Radiation and convection splits were determined for all internal loads [23–26]. The radiation temperature and relative humidity required for the PMV calculation were assumed to be 26°C (the mean wall temperature) and 50%, respectively. The convergence criterion for the simulations was defined to be 0.1% for all residuals of conservations.

In CFD, the grid type and resolution are critical factors affecting the results and were, therefore, tested in order to properly model the flow-physics inside of a space. A structured mesh with Cartesian coordinate system was selected and a parametric study was performed using simulations with increasing numbers of grid cells until the results converged on a common solution. Also, the aspect ratio of each grid was designed in order to assure good grid quality. A grid size of 1,436,400 cells was finally selected to satisfy both the accuracy requirement and computing cost. The study validated the built CFD model against the published experimental results. The validated model was then undergoing a set of parametric studies and analyses for the system optimisation.

sec.title: Taguchi Method
sec.p: The Taguchi method is a design of experiment approach that significantly reduces the number of cases in a parametric study compared to the factorial experiment design [27,28]. In an experiment with 3 factors (e.g. supply air velocity, flow rate and temperature) of 2 levels each (e.g. low and high), by using the Taguchi method the number of experiments can be reduced from 8 cases (23) to 4 cases, using the L4 orthogonal array. While this is not a significant reduction, in a more complicated experiment this method can reduce the number of cases by orders of magnitudes; for instance, for a case with 7 factors of 2 levels each, it can reduce from 128 cases (27) to only 8 cases, using the L8 orthogonal array. Similarly, for an experiment with 4 factors of 3 levels each, a L9 orthogonal array would be used to reduce the number of experiments from 81 cases (34) to only 9 cases. Depending on the number of factors and the number of factor levels being tested, different orthogonal arrays are used to describe the consolidated case set-up. These arrays have been well established and can be obtained for a wide range of factor and level combinations.

The Taguchi method usually uses the N-Way Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) to evaluate the results of the simulations, where N is the total number of levels being tested. The outcome of the ANOVA, determines how each factor (e.g. supply air velocity, flow rate and temperature) affects the system performance (e.g. thermal comfort, IAQ and energy) in terms of percent contribution to variance. This can be used to identify which parameters have the most influential effect on individual performance characteristics and overall system performance. The detailed calculation concept and process of ANOVA can be found in a number of references [27,29]. This paper will demonstrate the calculation process using the simulation results as follows.

In addition to analysing which factors have the most influence, the results of the abbreviated parametric study can also be used to predict and optimise the system performance using a discrete prediction/optimisation algorithm with Equation (1) [27]. This will allow predictions to be made of the performance of all possible factor combinations not required to be simulated by this method. This prediction method along with the percent contributions to variance will determine which factor-level combination will produce the optimal results in each individual performance metric and optimise the system comprehensively in terms of all three performance factors (e.g. thermal comfort, IAQ and energy): (1)Yopt=SN+(A¯x-SN)+(B¯x-SN)+(C¯x-SN) (1) where, Yopt is the predicted or optimal response, S is the sum of all tested responses, N is the number of test trials, and A¯x,B¯x,C¯x are the average factor responses of the most beneficial levels. This paper will demonstrate the application of this equation for PV system prediction and optimisation.

sec.title: Base Case Validations
sec.p:
The study built two reference base cases for comparison and validation purposes. The first base case simulated a conventional ceiling supply and return mixing ventilation only scenario that was used to comparatively assess the performance of cases with combined ceiling and PV systems. The second one simulated a combined ceiling and localised system (Round Movable Panel - RMP) that was tested in the lab by Cermak et al. [30]. The experimental results were used to verify the accuracy of the CFD model and simulation. Except the heating, ventilation and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems, both cases have exactly the same room scales and configurations. Figure 1 (left) shows the CFD model of the space that resembles a typical office environment with two workstations each containing a desk, computer monitor, computer tower, desk lamp, chair and occupant. The locations and geometries of these indoor objects were modeled according to the setups in the experiment of Cermak et al. [30]. The space was 5.4 m × 4.8 m × 2.6 m and air was supplied through the ceiling-mounted central mixing diffuser at a supply temperature of 20°C and a flow rate of 80 L/s. Four ceiling outlets were located at the corners of the room, with two rows of three ceiling lights. Figure 1 (right) illustrates the same room but with the extra RMP systems that were installed above the computer monitors. Air was supplied through the central ceiling diffuser and RMP devices with flow rates of 50 and 15 L/s respectively, with a supply temperature of 20°C at all inlets and RMP inlet velocity of 0.56 m/s. The laboratory experiment conducted in Cermak et al. [30] with the same configuration was used to validate the CFD model. Fig. 1.
Mixing ventilation base cases: without RMP (left) and with RMP (right).

This study focused on a comprehensive evaluation of system performance. Thermal comfort was evaluated using the PMV post-calculated by the simulation software and was measured at a height of 0.6 m for seated occupants in the occupied zone shown by Figure 2(a) [31]. IAQ was evaluated using the age of air predicted by the simulation software and measured in the BZ of the simulated occupant shown by Figure 2(b) [32]. Energy was computed using the conservation principle of energy with an estimated supply air mixture of 40% outside air and 60% return air. Figure 3 shows the predicted velocity and temperature distributions in the central plane across the occupants and Table 1 summarises the calculated performance data. As expected the simulation results for the mixing ventilation case without RMP reveal fairly uniform distributions for both the age of air and PMV. RMP provides a cool local supply air that effectively reaches the occupants’ BZs. The results in Table 1 indicate that a PV system can greatly improve the thermal comfort and IAQ while reducing the total energy cost. Fig. 2.
Analysis zone for CFD simulation results: thermal comfort (PMV) (left) and IAQ (age of air) (right). Fig. 3.
Simulated velocity and temperature distributions for both base cases. Table 1.
Calculated performance results of both base cases
Thermal comfort (PMV) IAQ (Age of air) (s) Energy (at OA = 32°C) (W)
Base case without RMP 0.38 850 972
Base case with RMP 0.26 153 754

Detailed comparison of simulated and measured results is shown in Figure 4. Experimental measurements were taken at two vertical poles around the workstations, and the averaged values of these two pole profiles are represented by the data points in the figure with their associated measurement uncertainties while the solid lines represent the simulation results. The experimental results for velocity and normalised temperature had associated measurement uncertainties of ±0.025 m/s and ±0.1°C, respectively [30]. The CFD results were extracted at the same vertical poles located at (0.5 m, 3 m) and (4 m, 3 m) with respect to the model origin, front lower left corner of the room. The data from the two poles was averaged and the temperature was normalised for an accurate comparison with the experimental data. The validation shows that the CFD model and simulation can accurately predict the global flow physics inside of the experiment chamber with a central and localised ventilation system. The validated model can then be used to develop new PV systems for optimal thermal comfort, IAQ and energy performance. Fig. 4.
Experimental validations of CFD results.

sec.title: Simulation Cases
sec.p:
This research developed a new ATD in an attempt to achieve improved thermal comfort, IAQ and energy performance when compared to the base cases. This new ATD is called the Computer Perimeter Grill (CPG). The CPG borders the computer screen in front of the seated occupant and supplies fresh conditioned air directly to the BZ and occupied area. The same room as the base cases was used for a parametric study of the CPG with the Taguchi design of experiment method. The central overhead diffuser velocity was kept constant at 2 m/s to be constant with the base case (with RMP), and a grille/nozzle diffuser type was used with y–z and x–z angles of 45° and 60°, respectively. The L4 orthogonal array [27] was selected for this parametric study which includes three factors with two levels each. Key factors (supply air velocity, flow rate and temperature) were studied with high and low level operating characteristics which represent the recommended system operating parameter ranges collected from the literatures. Figure 5 shows the CFD model of the room with CPG. Table 2 shows the three factors and the corresponding low and high level definitions, as well as the factor level set-up for each case. Figures 6 and 7 show the simulation results for thermal comfort and IAQ, respectively, and Table 3 summarises the calculated performance results. Fig. 5.
Simulated office space with mixing ventilation and CPG. Fig. 6.
Predicted thermal comfort (PMV): Case 1 (top-left), Case 2 (top-right), Case 3 (bottom-left), Case 4 (bottom-right). Fig. 7.
Predicted IAQ (Age of Air): Case 1 (top-left), Case 2 (top-right), Case 3 (bottom-left), Case 4 (bottom-right). Table 2.
L4 orthogonal array of factor level set-up for parametric study [right] and associated factor and level definitions [left]
Table 3.
Summary of calculated performance results
Thermal comfort (PMV) IAQ (Age of air) (s) Energy (at OA = 32°C) (W)
CPG case 1 0.52 1339 349
CPG case 2 0.50 231 507
CPG case 3 0.64 1064 239
CPG case 4 0.23 470 750

sec.title: Results Analysis
sec.p: The N-Way ANOVA method was employed to analyse the simulation results and evaluate the influence of each factor (velocity, flow rate, supply temperature) at two levels: high and low (N = 2). Three separate ANOVA calculations were conducted to find each factor's effect on system performance: thermal comfort, IAQ and energy. The calculated percent contribution of each factor to variance results was normalised based on the percent difference between the factor's low and high levels (see Sample Calculation 1 in theAppendix).

Table 4 presents the calculated percent contribution of each factor to the variance results of interest (PMV, IAQ and energy) using the ANOVA method. A conventional sensitivity study was also conducted to verify the percent contribution variation results obtained by the ANOVA analysis. The numerical sensitivity study included varying the levels of each factor individually from the tested low level to the high level. Percent variance of the sensitivity study was then calculated with respect to the simulated case with all three factors at their respective low levels (see Sample Calculation 2 in the Appendix). Comparison of the percent contributions of all the factors calculated by both methods is presented in Table 4. Observed good agreement indicates the feasibility and effectiveness of the Taguchi method. The Taguchi method with the ANOVA analysis significantly can reduce the number of the cases that are required by the conventional sensitivity study to reach the same conclusions. Table 4.
Comparison of percent contributions of factors calculated by ANOVA and sensitivity study
Velocity Flow rate Temperature
Normalised % contribution to variance, PMV
ANOVA 1.2% 11.8% 86.9%
Sensitivity study 0.0% 35.2% 64.8%
Normalised % contribution to variance, IAQ
ANOVA 0.0% 54.9% 45.1%
Sensitivity study 0.3% 62.1% 37.6%
Normalised % contribution to variance, energy
ANOVA 0.8% 28.3% 70.9%
Sensitivity study 8.2% 23.8% 67.9%

Table 4 exhibits that supply air velocity has little effect on all three categories as expected because both the low and high range are capable of penetrating the thermal plume and provide the personalised air into the occupied area. The effects of supply air flow rate and temperature on the thermal comfort are also consistent with the expectation that flow rate and temperature have the greatest effect on PMV. In terms of IAQ, temperature had a surprisingly large contribution to variance. It was discovered in the sensitivity study that the buoyancy effects of the temperature change had a significant influence on the airflow in the BZ. Figure 8 shows the velocity vector distribution comparison between the low and high supply temperature cases, and the significant effect of buoyancy on the fresh air being provided to the BZ. Fig. 8.
Sensitivity study results – velocity vectors with Ts = 20°C (left) and Ts = 23°C (right).

The energy analysis revealed that the effects of supply air temperature were significantly greater than the effects of flow rate. To verify these results, the partial derivatives of the energy equation were taken with respect to supply flow rate and supply temperature and a sample calculation was conducted: (2)Q=ρCpV.(Ts-0.4To-0.6*TR) (2) (3)dQdTs=ρCpV.(1-0.6*dTRdTs) (3) (4)dQdV.=ρCp(Ts-0.4*To-0.6*TR-0.6V.dTRdV.) (4) where, Q is the cooling energy consumption, ρ is the air density, Cp is the air specific heat, V. is supply air total volume flow rate, Ts is the supply air temperature, To is the outdoor air temperature and TR is the return air temperature. The return air temperature was affected by the supply air temperature and flow rate and therefore, dTR/dTs and dTR/dV were calculated from the results of the sensitivity study where the flow rate and supply temperature levels were varied independently, resulting in dTRdTs=0.2535 and dTRdV.=-0.0216. For a case with V. = 34 L/s, Ts = 20°C and constant To=32°C, the predicted TR=26.3°C. This yields: dQdTs=34.5 and dQdV.=-9.72. The magnitude of the change in energy with respect to supply air temperature has a greater effect than the magnitude of the change in energy with respect to supply air volume flow rate, which is consistent with the percent contribution to variance predictions from the statistical analysis.

The results confirm that the CPG in conjunction with mixing ventilation is a successful ATD that improves the thermal comfort, IAQ and energy performance compared to the base case (mixing only). The CPG is also found to have comparable (or slightly improved) performance characteristics over the RMP in thermal comfort and energy, but the IAQ of the RMP outperformed the CPG (the validated base case with RMP compared to the Taguchi Method case 4, both have the same operating characteristic settings).

sec.title: System Performance Prediction and Optimisation
sec.p:
To find the optimal factor combinations for all performance metrics of interest, it is important to predict the system performance for every possible factor combination. Rather than directly simulating all these 8 cases (2×2×2) in CFD for this test case with 3 factors (i.e. supply air velocity, flow rate and temperature) of 2 levels each (low and high), the discrete prediction of system response algorithm, Equation (1), was used for the quick system performance prediction. Table 5 shows the discrete prediction of every possible factor level combination, highlighting performance characteristic improvements compared to the base case (mixing only). Table 5.
Prediction of system performance for the numerical experiment
Performance characteristic Factor levels (supply air velocity, flow rate, temperature: 1-low; 2-high)
2_2_2 2_2_1 2_1_2 2_1_1 1_2_2 1_1_2 1_2_1 1_1_1 Base case
Thermal comfort 0.42 0.23 0.64 0.44 0.50 0.72 0.31 0.52 0.38
IAQ 213 470 1064 1321 231 1083 488 1339 850
Energy 573 750 239 415 507 172 683 349 972

These results show that there are multiple operational characteristics setting combinations (highlighted in shadow) for the system using the localised CPG and central ventilation that can achieve improvements in thermal comfort, IAQ and energy compared to a system with only mixing ventilation. Depending on the design focus or goal, different systems can be proposed and developed to maximise the performance improvement in one particular aspect. For instance, if the system tested in this research were to be optimised for thermal comfort, the best combination of PV operating characteristics would be factor levels (2_2_1): V = 0.56 m/s, V. = 15 L/s and Ts = 20°C. The optimal PV operating characteristics for IAQ would be factor levels (2_2_2): V = 0.56 m/s, V. = 15 L/s and Ts = 23°C. And finally, the optimal PV operating characteristics for energy would be factor levels (1_1_2): V = 0.2 m/s, V. = 2.5 L/s and Ts = 23°C. It will, however, be rather challenging to optimise a PV system for all best performance characteristics. By compromising the system operating characteristics and weighting the contribution of each factor to variance, a system can be optimised to achieve most savings in all three performance characteristics, such as with the factor levels (2_2_1) and (1_2_1). However, note that no optimised system will be capable of achieving the performance of the preferred combination for every performance metric.

sec.title: Verification of System Performance Prediction
sec.p:
The study further compared the predicted values for thermal comfort, IAQ and energy performance based on the discrete prediction of system response algorithm to the full CFD simulations using the same parameter setups. As shown in Table 6, the discrete predictions of system response results show excellent agreement with those from the direct CFD simulations, illustrating the discrete prediction algorithm's ability to predict the performance of cases not required by the Taguchi analysis. Average uncertainties were found not to exceed 10%, which is included in the optimisation threshold. Table 6.
Comparison of discrete prediction algorithm and full CFD sensitivity simulation
Taguchi prediction Sensitivity simulation % Difference
IAQ PMV Energy IAQ PMV Energy IAQ PMV Energy
2_1_1 1321 0.44 415 1264 0.52 347 −4% 16% −18%
1_2_1 488 0.31 683 387 0.25 754 −23% −20% 10%
1_1_2 1083 0.72 172 1093 0.65 238 1% −11% 32%
2_2_2 244 0.45 507 213 0.42 573 −14% −7% 12%
Averages −10% −5% 9%

sec.title: Alternative System Optimisation Method
sec.p:
Although much more effective than the full CFD modeling, using the discrete prediction of system response algorithm can still be cumbersome when a large number of factors and levels are considered. This study, hence, proposed another method that can identify the most optimal factor combinations for the best overall system performance based on the limited Taguchi simulation results. To achieve this, the influence of each factor on the different performance metrics would need to be combined which requires an equivalent comparison. The percent contribution to variance results normalised by the percent difference between the high and low levels, with no scaling factor, allowed the percent contribution to variance results based on a percent difference to be analysed as equivalent for each factor and performance metric (see Sample Calculation 1 in the Appendix). For each factor, the percent contribution to variance values coinciding with the preferred levels for the different performance metrics, are summed based on the individual levels. Then whichever preferred factor level is associated with the largest contribution to variance is selected as the optimal factor level setting. If the difference between the contributions to variance for each factor is less than a defined threshold, then either factor level can be used, and multiple optimal factor configurations can be obtained. For this study, a threshold is defined as the uncertainty associated with the analysis. The average prediction uncertainty (10%), in addition to the average influence of factor interactions (5%), was used as the optimisation threshold. Therefore, a 15% threshold was used for the optimisation. Table 7 shows the normalised, but not scaled contributions to variance for the different factors on the three performance metrics. Table 7.
Normalised but not scaled contribution to variance of the numerical experiment
Velocity Flow rate Temperature
IAQ 0.02% 67.71% 55.62%
Thermal comfort 3.95% 37.82% 278.22%
Energy 1.68% 56.08% 140.72%

The normalised but not scaled percent contributions to variance results are combined with the preferred factor combinations for each individual performance metric, that is, (2_2_2) for IAQ, (2_2_1) for thermal comfort and (1_1_2) for energy. Table 8 shows the calculation process of the comprehensive optimisation described earlier, and uses the data from the previous two tables to obtain the results. Table 8.
Comprehensive optimisation results for the numerical experiment
Level Velocity Flow rate Temperature
1 2 1 2 1 2
IAQ
0.02%
67.71%
55.62%
Thermal comfort
3.95%
37.82% 278.22%
Energy 1.68%
56.08%
140.72%
Sum 1.68% 3.97% 56.08% 105.53% 278.22% 196.34%
Difference 2.29% 49.46% 81.88%
Optimal level setting 1 or 2 2 1

As per the results, two factor combinations are identified that can obtain optimal results and savings in all three performance metrics – factor combinations 2_2_1 and 1_2_1, which match the prior finding from the complete search of various possible factor combinations.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This paper proposes a Taguchi-method-based simulation approach that can help predict the influence of operating parameters of PV systems on the system performance. The predicted influence matches the understanding in physics. The study further developed two new methods for finding the best system parameters based on the limited Taguchi simulation results, both of which were verified by the full CFD modeling using a validated CFD model. Multiple solutions were obtained for the optimised system where improvements in thermal comfort, IAQ and energy performance were achieved in comparison to a system with mixing ventilation only.

With the tested CPG-PV system, the study finds that within a reasonable range of the operating parameters, supply air temperature has a significant influence on thermal comfort, IAQ and energy; volume flow rate has a significant effect on IAQ and minor effects on thermal comfort and energy; and velocity has minor effects on all performance characteristics.

The proposed system optimisation approach can be viably applicable for the needs of different building types and occupants. The multiple solutions found for an optimised system would suggest a need for weighting the importance of each performance characteristic according to the needs of the building/occupants. Combining the weighting factors, percent contribution to variance, and prediction of system response will result in a single solution that may provide the overall optimal system performance. However, experiments with more factors and greater than 2 factor level settings may be required to achieve a more detailed optimisation of system performance.

CermakRMelikovAForejtLKovarO: Performance of personalized ventilation in conjunction with mixing and displacement ventilation: HVAC&R Res 2006;12(2):295–311.

ASHRAE Standard Project Committee 55: Thermal Environmental Conditions for Human Occupancy - ANSI/ASHRAE Standard 55-2004. Atlanta, American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers, 2004.

ASHRAE Standard Project Committee 62: Ventilation for Acceptable Indoor Air Quality - ANSI/ASHRAE Standard 62.1-2004. Atlanta, American Society of Heating, Refrigeration, and Air-Condition Engineers, 2004.

sec.p: Sample Calculation 1: Velocity Contribution to Variance on PMV – ANOVA Calculation

This sample calculation takes the PMV results from the 4 cases simulated for the Taguchi parametric study, and calculates the percent contribution to variance from velocity on PMV. The results for the 4 cases are shown in the following table:
Thermal comfort (PMV) Velocity level
CPG case 1 0.525 1-low
CPG case 2 0.504 1-low
CPG case 3 0.639 2-high
CPG case 4 0.229 2-high
TheaveragePMVresultsforLevel1- low velocities=0.525+0.5042=0.5145 TheaveragePMVresultsforLevel2- high velocities=0.639+0.2292=0.434 Therefore, the Main Effect of velocity on PMV=0.434-0.5145=-0.08

Next, the Total Sum of Squares is calculated for the PMV results Total Sum of Squares=(0.5252+0.5042+0.6392+0.2292)-(0.525+0.504+0.639+0.229)24=0.0907 The Sum of Squares for only the effects of velocity iscalculated by (Main Effect)2=(-0.08)2=0.0064 Therefore, the Percent Contribution of Velocity toVariance on PMV=0.00640.0907×100=7.1%

The Normalised Contribution to Variance uses the percent difference between the factor's low and high levels and a scaling factor, which is determined to scale the normalised percent contribution to variance values for all three factors so that the sum is equal to 100%. The scaling factor for this example was found to be 0.3125. %Difference=0.56m/s-0.2m/s0.2m/s×100=180%Normalised Contribution to Variance=7.1%180%×0.3125=1.2%
Sample Calculation 2: Velocity Contribution to Variance on PMV – Sensitivity Study Calculation

This sample calculation takes the PMV results from the sensitivity study and calculates the percent contribution to variance from velocity on PMV. The results for the sensitivity study are shown in the following table:
Thermal comfort (PMV)
Low velocity 0.5247
High velocity 0.5236

The Percent Contribution of Velocity to Variance on PMV is calculated using the calculated variance from the simulation results: PMVAverage=0.5247+0.52362=0.52415 The Variance from velocity was calculated to be=(0.5247-0.52415)2+(0.5236-0.52415)22=3.0×10-7
The Total Variance found from all three factors was 0.0386. Therefore, the Percent Contribution of Velocity to Variance=3.0×10-70.0386×100=0.000777%

The Normalised Contribution to Variance uses the percent difference between the factors low and high levels: %Difference=0.56m/s-0.2m/s0.2m/s×100=180%Normalised Contribution to Variance=0.000777%180%×100=0.00043%
Sample Calculation 3: Taguchi Prediction of IAQ (Age of Air) for High Velocity Sensitivity Study Case – Discrete Prediction/Optimisation Algorithm Calculation

This sample calculation takes the IAQ results from the 4 cases simulated for the Taguchi parametric study, and calculates the predicted IAQ performance for a case with high-level velocity, low-level flow rate and low-level supply temperature. The results for the 4 cases are shown in the following table: The average IAQ results for Level 2- high velocities=1064+4702=767s The average IAQ results for Level 1- low flow rates=1339+10642=1201.5s TheaverageIAQresultsforLevel1-lowsupply temperature=1339+4702=904.5s The total average results=1339+231+1064+4704=776s The Predicted Response is Y2_1_1=776+(767-776)+(1201.5-776)+(904.5-776)=1321s
IAQ (age of air) (s) Velocity level Flow rate level Supply temperature level
CPG case 1 1339 1-low 1-low 1-low
CPG case 2 231 1-low 2-high 2-high
CPG case 3 1064 2-high 1-low 2-high
CPG case 4 470 2-high 2-high 1-low
